Award.AwardTitle: Developing high-resolution tremor catalogs to constrain numerical models of slow slip
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major discoveries in geophysics in the past decade has been that of ?episodic slow slip and tremor? in many of the world?s subduction zones. Most known faults either slip steadily at the plate tectonic rate (a few centimeters per year), or spend most of the time ?locked? and slip only during short-lived earthquakes, with slip speeds of order 1 m/sec and propagation speeds of order 3 km/sec (the sound speed of rock). Slow slip events, on the other hand, have average slip speeds of only ~0.1 micron/s and propagate up to 300 km along strike at remarkably reproducible speeds of roughly 10 km/day. Coincident in time and space with the geodetically-observed slow slip is a seismic signal termed ?tectonic tremor?. Unlike typical earthquakes, which have impulsive seismic wave arrivals, tremor is a low-amplitude signal that can last for hours and that most often lacks clearly identifiable seismic wave arrivals. Slow slip has now been discovered in nearly all subduction regions with sufficient instrumentation to see it, if it were present. Tremor is coincident in space and time with may slow slip events, and has also been discovered on the deep extension of the San Andreas fault in California. In addition to representing a previously unrecognized style of fault slip, episodic slow slip is relevant to seismic hazards because it increases the stressing rate on the locked portions of faults capable of producing magnitude 9 earthquakes. It has also been proposed that it may delimit the down-dip extent of slip during those earthquakes (bringing, notably, strong ground shaking considerably closer to downtown Seattle than had previously been thought).

Because the resolution of geodetic data for deep faults is quite poor, tremor locations currently provide our most detailed images of the space-time history of slow slip. But because tremor lacks clear wave arrivals and can be active on multiple regions of the fault simultaneously, it cannot be located using standard techniques. We are developing a new tremor detection algorithm that, applied to the subduction zone off the coast of the Pacific Northwest, is currently producing the most accurate tremor locations in the world. Rather than the more traditional method of comparing seismograms from different time windows at the same station, it compares the same time windows at different stations. Relative location errors are often less than 1 km, allowing us to image in great detail secondary tremor fronts that arise behind, and propagate 1?2 orders of magnitude faster than, the main front of the slow slip event. By imaging these secondary fronts and their relation to the main with high fidelity, we expect to learn more about the processes underlying slow slip. In addition, studies of tremor are proliferating worldwide, but as yet there is no single, generally-agreed-upon method for locating it. By comparing our location method with more traditional methods and combining aspects of each, we stand to learn much about how to improve tremor location algorithms and how to apply this knowledge in other regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Until recently, it was thought that earthquakes either slipped steadily at the plate tectonic rate, or else spent most of their lifetime locked, and slipped only during brief earthquakes.  Around the year 2000 a third style of behavior was discovered, deep within subduction zones, where the fault periodically accelerated to perhaps 100 times the plate rate, but then slowed down again without producing an earthquake.  These "slow slip events" have since been observed in almost every subduction zone with sufficient instrumentation to detect them if they were present.  They propagate at rates of kilometers per day, compared to the kilometers per second typical of regular earthquakes, and are equivalent in size to magnitude 6 or larger earthquakes but last for weeks rather than seconds.  They are of interest from a seismic hazards standpoint because they increase the stress and stressing rate on the locked, shallower portions of subduction zone faults capable of generating magnitude 9 earthquakes.  

Coincident in space and time with the geodetically-observed slow slip events is a second recently discovered signal termed "tectonic tremor", this one seen on seismometers.  Tremor is a low-amplitude, extended-duration signal lacking obvious P-wave and S-wave arrivals.  It is comprised of myriad, overlapping "low frequency earthquakes", comparable to magnitude 1 to 2 earthquakes in size but apparently taking about 10 times longer (a few tenths of a second) to rupture.  Because tremor lacks obvious wave arrivals, standard earthquake location methods yield location errors of 10 kilometers or more.  Nonetheless, because the temporal and spatial resolution of the geodetic observations are so low, under the assumption that tremor and slow slip track each other, tremor catalogs provide the most accurate and complete images of slow slip avaialble to us.

Tremor and episodic slow slip are of interest scientifically because they are showing us how the deepest portions of plate boundary faults operate.  Episodic slow slip is somewhat surprising, in that the simplest equations commonly used predict that any fault that accelerates above the plate tectonic driving rate (centimeters/year) should accelerate all the way to earthquake slip speeds (meters/second) before slowing down.  Since its discovery, several physical mechansims capable of generating episodic slow slip have been proposed, but distinguishing between them will require additional observational constraints.  

The goal of this project was to provide these additional observational constraints by obtaining more accurate locations for tremor.  We have developed a method we call "cross-station", which compares the same time window of tremor at 3 stations separated by up to a few tens of kilometers.  Beneath southern Vancouver Island (Canada), the Olympic Peninsula (Washington State), Guerrero (Mexico), and the Kii Peninsula (Japan), we have obtained relative location errors of a few hundered meters to a couple of kilometers, depending upon the available station spacing, the contribution of reflected seismic waves to the seismiograms, and the strength of the tremor signal.  This makes our tremor catalogs the most accurate available for these regions.  By comparing our method to more standard methods we have learned why it works where it works, have modified it to adapt to different observational conditions in different subduction zones, and have gained insight that might improve future deployments of seismic networks.

We find that although the main tremor front (and by inference the main slow slip front) propagates along the strike of the subduction zone at rates of roughly 10 kilometers/day, on shorter time scales we almost never see propagation in this direction.  Instead, our tremor catalogs consist of short bursts of tremor that migrate along the main front, even when that front is curved, or that start at the main front and propagate backwards, at speeds 10 to 100 times faster than the apparent speed of the main front.  The apparent propagation of the main front arises from the slow advance of the initiation points of these faster secondary tremor migrations.  At any one spot, the recurrence interval between the bursts is short (tens of minutes) immediately following the arrival of the main front, and then gradually increases unitl becoming locked in phase with the roughly 12-hour and (sometimes) the 24-hour tidal cycles.  Both observations, the propagation behavior of the secondary tremor migrations and their increasing recurrence interval, have provided useful constraints on numerical models of slow slip.  Our observations are also providing useful constraints on the nature of tectonic tremor and low frequency earthquakes, which remain enigmatic nearly 20 years after their discovery.
